title: NaOH-HCl titration curve - enthalpy change value

content.description: To determine the concentration of a NaOH(aq) solution, a student titrated a 50. mL sample with 0.10 M HCl(aq) . The reaction is represented by the equation above. The titration is monitored using a pH meter, and the experimental results are plotted in the graph below.
content.question: A student mixes a 10.0 mL sample of 1.0 M NaOH(aq) with a 10.0 mL sample of 1.0 M HCl(aq) in a polystyrene container. The temperature of the solutions before mixing was 20.0°C. If the final temperature of the mixture is 26.0°C, what is the experimental value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup> <mi>H</mi> <mrow> <mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow> <mo>∘</mo> </msubsup> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGuoGaamisam aaDaaaleaacaWGYbGaamiEaiaad6gaaeaacqWIyiYBaaaaaa@3F33@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>? (Assume that the solution mixture has a specific heat of 4.2 J/(g•K) and a density of 1.0 g/mL.)

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
